title: A day in the life of a Mongolian queen - Anne F. Broadbridge

multiple-choice.question: What is Queen Boraqchin's role in the Mongolian Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: She is the emperor of the Mongolian Empire.

options.label: B
options.text: She is the wife of Batu Khan and the manager of a city of thousands.

options.label: C
options.text: She is a shepherd responsible for the empire's flocks.

options.label: D
options.text: She is a commander of the empire's army.

multiple-choice.question: Why does Queen Boraqchin move the city twice a year?

options.label: A
options.text: To expand the empire's territory.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure constant water and lush grass in summer, and protection from harsh winds in winter.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid enemy attacks.

options.label: D
options.text: To participate in trade fairs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the yurt in Mongolian culture?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a symbol of wealth and status.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a portable home that can be easily set up and taken down.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a place of worship.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a center of commerce.

multiple-choice.question: What is Queen Boraqchin's approach to ruling the empire?

options.label: A
options.text: She is a hands-off ruler who delegates tasks to her servants.

options.label: B
options.text: She is a hands-on ruler who is involved in the day-to-day activities of the empire.

options.label: C
options.text: She is a strict ruler who enforces harsh punishments.

options.label: D
options.text: She is a distant ruler who is not involved in the affairs of the empire.

multiple-choice.question: What is the composition of the procession that Queen Boraqchin leads?

options.label: A
options.text: It consists only of the royal family and their servants.

options.label: B
options.text: It consists of the royal family, followed by the civilian city, including holy men, families, tradesmen, and shepherds.

options.label: C
options.text: It consists of the royal family, followed by the army and then the civilian city.

options.label: D
options.text: It consists of the royal family, followed by the imperial guards and then the civilian city.

title: "The Nutritionist" by Andrea Gibson

multiple-choice.question: What was the nutritionist's advice to the speaker in the poem "The Nutritionist"?

options.label: A
options.text: To eat 13 turnips a day to be grounded and rooted.

options.label: B
options.text: To spend 3 hours a day sitting in a dark closet with eyes closed and ears plugged.

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on the outbreaths and care more about what to give than what to get.

options.label: D
options.text: To take medication such as klonopin, lamictil, lithium, or Xanax.

multiple-choice.question: What was the psychic's advice to the speaker in the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: To stop worrying and focus on finding a good man soon.

options.label: B
options.text: To spend more time sitting in a dark closet with eyes closed and ears plugged.

options.label: C
options.text: To take medication to forget the trauma.

options.label: D
options.text: To write a poem about the grief inside.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to those who have ever wanted to die?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are alone in their feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: That they should keep their grief to themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: That reminding themselves that others feel the same way can be healing.

options.label: D
options.text: That they should try to forget their trauma.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker compare a heavy heart to?

options.label: A
options.text: A phone booth with a red cape inside.

options.label: B
options.text: A falling house with a broken gutter.

options.label: C
options.text: A truck with a bumper sticker.

options.label: D
options.text: A dandelion losing its mind in the wind.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the listener?

options.label: A
options.text: To give up and lose hope.

options.label: B
options.text: To stay with them and keep fighting.

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on the outbreaths and care more about what to give than what to get.

options.label: D
options.text: To take medication to forget the trauma.

title: The truth about electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) - Helen M. Farrell

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary use of Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) in modern medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: To treat mild cases of depression

options.label: B
options.text: To treat severe cases of major depression or bipolar disorder

options.label: C
options.text: To treat anxiety disorders

options.label: D
options.text: To treat personality disorders

multiple-choice.question: How has ECT changed since its early years?

options.label: A
options.text: It now uses a stronger electrical current

options.label: B
options.text: It now causes a longer, more intense seizure

options.label: C
options.text: It now uses general anesthesia and a muscle relaxant to minimize physical effects

options.label: D
options.text: It is no longer used to treat mental health conditions

multiple-choice.question: What is a common side effect of ECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Memory loss of events from years ago

options.label: B
options.text: Increased energy and alertness

options.label: C
options.text: Trouble remembering what happened right before a session

options.label: D
options.text: Increased appetite

multiple-choice.question: Why is ECT thought to be effective in treating depression?

options.label: A
options.text: It alters brain chemistry by releasing certain neurotransmitters

options.label: B
options.text: It stimulates the flow of hormones that reduce symptoms of depression

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the production of serotonin in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

multiple-choice.question: What is often paired with ECT to make it more effective?

options.label: A
options.text: Psychotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Medication

options.label: C
options.text: Lifestyle changes

options.label: D
options.text: Alternative therapies

title: What happens in your brain when you pay attention? - Mehdi Ordikhani-Seyedlar

multiple-choice.question: What are the two ways to direct attention?

options.text: Focused attention and divided attention

options.label: B
options.text: Overt attention and covert attention

options.label: C
options.text: Selective attention and sustained attention

options.label: D
options.text: Alternating attention and simultaneous attention

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The brain signals from the frontal area are stronger

options.label: C
options.text: The brain signals from both the back and frontal areas are weaker

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To filter out distractions and focus on relevant information

options.label: C
options.text: To control eye movements

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate emotions

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Enabling people with paralysis to communicate through a computer

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to process visual information quickly

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to regulate emotions

title: Can you solve the multiplying rabbits riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: How many habitat cells are there in the lab where the nano-rabbits are being kept?
How many rabbits can each cell hold before they break free and overrun the world?
What is the primary way that the nano-rabbits reproduce?

options.label: A
options.text: Each rabbit breeds with every other rabbit in the same cell.

options.label: B
options.text: Each rabbit breeds with every rabbit in the horizontally adjacent cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Each rabbit breeds with every rabbit in the vertically adjacent cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Each rabbit breeds with every rabbit in the diagonally adjacent cells.

multiple-choice.question: How many trailing zeros should there be at the end of the count of rabbits in the bottom habitat?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibonacci sequence

options.label: B
options.text: Pascal's triangle

options.label: C
options.text: Pythagorean theorem

options.label: D
options.text: Euclidean algorithm

title: Can you survive nuclear fallout? - Brooke Buddemeier and Jessica S. Wieder

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way to protect oneself from the shockwave, heat, and radiation of a nuclear detonation?

options.label: A
options.text: Staying outside and away from buildings

options.label: B
options.text: Getting and staying inside a sturdy building

options.label: C
options.text: Trying to outrun the shockwave

options.label: D
options.text: Staying in a vehicle

options.label: A
options.text: The initial blast and shockwave

options.label: B
options.text: The heat generated by the explosion

options.label: C
options.text: Radioactive particles called fallout

options.label: D
options.text: The destruction of buildings and infrastructure

multiple-choice.question: What can reduce the effects of radiation from fallout?

options.label: A
options.text: Thin layers of material, such as clothing or paper

options.label: B
options.text: Thick layers of steel, concrete, and packed earth

options.label: C
options.text: Staying outside and exposing oneself to the radiation

options.label: D
options.text: Trying to outrun the radiation

multiple-choice.question: How long should one stay inside to avoid the most serious effects of radiation from fallout?

options.label: A
options.text: At least 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: At least 24 hours

options.label: C
options.text: At least 1 week

options.label: D
options.text: At least 1 month

multiple-choice.question: What should someone do if they get caught in the fallout and then find a safe space?

options.label: B
options.text: Try to shake off the fallout particles

options.label: C
options.text: Leave the safe space and try to find a new one

options.label: D
options.text: Stay in the safe space and do nothing

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition set by the troll to release all the creatures?

options.label: B
options.text: If you say something true, I'll release all these creatures.

options.text: If you say something paradoxical, I'll release all these creatures.

options.text: If you say something funny, I'll release all these creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: If you say something false, I'll release your brother.

options.text: If you say something paradoxical, I'll release your brother.

title: The dangerous race for the South Pole - Elizabeth Leane

multiple-choice.question: Who had spent nearly two years preparing his Arctic expedition, but later decided to head to the South Pole instead?

options.label: A
options.text: Robert F. Scott

options.label: B
options.text: Roald Amundsen

options.label: C
options.text: Fridtjof Nansen

options.label: D
options.text: Frederick Cook

multiple-choice.question: Why did Roald Amundsen decide to alter the course of his voyage from the North Pole to the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: He received new funding to explore the South Pole.

options.label: B
options.text: He heard that the American explorers Frederick Cook and Robert Peary had staked rival claims to reaching the North Pole.

options.label: C
options.text: He was informed that the South Pole was easier to reach than the North Pole.

options.label: D
options.text: He was advised by Fridtjof Nansen to explore the South Pole instead.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference between Amundsen's and Scott's expeditions to the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: Amundsen's team was larger than Scott's team.

options.label: B
options.text: Scott's team was more focused on scientific research than Amundsen's team.

options.label: C
options.text: Amundsen's team used more advanced technology than Scott's team.

options.label: D
options.text: Scott's team traveled with more men and equipment than Amundsen's team.

multiple-choice.question: How did Amundsen's team ensure that they had reached the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: They used a GPS device to confirm their location.

options.label: B
options.text: They traversed the area in a grid to make sure they covered the Pole's location.

options.label: C
options.text: They followed the path of Ernest Shackleton's earlier attempt to reach the pole.

options.label: D
options.text: They relied on their Inuit guides to confirm their location.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Scott's party when they finally reached the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: They were the first team to reach the South Pole.

options.label: B
options.text: They found Amundsen's team waiting for them at the South Pole.

options.label: C
options.text: They lost two men to frostbite, starvation, and exhaustion on the way back to their camp.

options.label: D
options.text: They were rescued by a team sent from their base.

title: Why you should talk to strangers - Kio Stark

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about talking to strangers?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a necessary part of daily life.

options.label: B
options.text: That it can lead to meaningful and beautiful connections.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is a waste of time.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is too awkward and uncomfortable.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary reason we are uneasy around strangers?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we have no context and don't know their intentions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are naturally introverted.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are afraid of being hurt.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are too busy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "fleeting intimacy" that the speaker mentions?

options.label: A
options.text: A brief experience of emotional connection with a stranger.

options.label: B
options.text: A long-term relationship with someone.

options.label: C
options.text: A feeling of unease around strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of anxiety disorder.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do we often communicate more effectively with strangers than with people we are close to?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we have a bias towards people we are close to and expect them to understand us.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are more comfortable around strangers.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are more honest with strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are more open-minded around strangers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "dogs and babies principle" that the speaker mentions?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is always easy to talk to someone on the street.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is always awkward to talk to someone on the street.

options.label: C
options.text: That talking to someone's dog or baby can be a social conduit to the person.

options.label: D
options.text: That talking to someone's dog or baby is always a bad idea.

title: Why are we the only humans left?

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many years ago did Neanderthals and modern humans coexist on the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: 10,000 years ago

options.label: B
options.text: 20,000 years ago

options.label: C
options.text: 50,000 years ago

options.label: D
options.text: 100,000 years ago

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the main reasons why Neanderthals were able to survive in cold northern climates?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to adapt to new technologies

options.label: B
options.text: Their large brain size

options.label: C
options.text: Their physical adaptations, such as a big brow ridge and huge nose

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to communicate with each other through complex language

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: FOXP3

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the time travel riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the minimum number of nodules needed to be certain of creating a red or blue triangle and getting back to the present?
What is the name of the branch of mathematics that developed from the problem of determining the minimum number of nodules needed to create a red or blue triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: Ramsey Theory

options.label: B
options.text: Temporal Instability Theory

options.label: C
options.text: Tachyon Entanglement Theory

options.label: D
options.text: Chrono-Nodule Theory

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a red or blue triangle is created with a nodule at each point?

options.label: A
options.text: The portal collapses

options.label: B
options.text: A doorway through time is opened

options.label: C
options.text: The nodules become unstable

options.label: D
options.text: The connections between the nodules change color

multiple-choice.question: Why is it better to bring fewer nodules?

options.label: A
options.text: Because each nodule increases the chances of creating a red or blue triangle

options.label: B
options.text: Because each nodule decreases the chances of creating a red or blue triangle

options.label: C
options.text: Because each nodule creates a temporal instability that raises the chances the portal might collapse

options.label: D
options.text: Because each nodule makes it easier to carry

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of activating six nodules and considering how the sixth nodule might connect to the other five?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no guarantee of creating a red or blue triangle

options.label: B
options.text: There is a possibility of creating a red or blue triangle, but it's not certain

options.label: C
options.text: There is a guarantee of creating a red or blue triangle, but only if the connections are all the same color

options.label: D
options.text: There is a guarantee of creating a red or blue triangle, regardless of the colors of the connections

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: He is haunted by memories of World War II.

options.label: D
options.text: He is struggling with his life as a middle-aged optometrist.

options.label: A
options.text: Kurt Vonnegut's experiences as a prisoner of war in Dresden.

options.label: B
options.text: Kurt Vonnegut's studies of anthropology and the shapes of stories.

options.label: C
options.text: Kurt Vonnegut's fascination with science fiction and aliens.

options.label: D
options.text: Kurt Vonnegut's work as an optometrist.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of time according to the Tralfamadorians in Kurt Vonnegut's works?

options.label: A
options.text: Time is linear and progresses from past to present to future.

options.label: B
options.text: Time is cyclical and events repeat themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: All moments, past, present, and future, always exist simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: Time is relative and depends on individual perspectives.

multiple-choice.question: What is the central theme of the fictional religion of Bokonism in Kurt Vonnegut's Cat's Cradle?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of honesty and truth.

options.label: B
options.text: The power of love and relationships.

options.label: C
options.text: The acceptance of harmless lies as a means to find meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: The rejection of all forms of authority.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate message of hope that Kurt Vonnegut conveys through his works?

options.label: A
options.text: That humanity is doomed to repeat its mistakes.

options.label: B
options.text: That individualism is the key to success.

options.label: C
options.text: That we are all here to help each other get through life's challenges.

options.label: D
options.text: That technology will solve all our problems.

title: Can you solve the giant iron riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: How many working batteries are required to power up the Giant Iron?
How many possible combinations of batteries are there if you take all eight batteries?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The group has one good battery.

options.label: C
options.text: The group has either one good battery or none at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The group has no good batteries.

options.label: C
options.text: You will get a working result in 5 tries or less.

options.label: D

title: The nightmare videos of childrens' YouTube — James Bridle

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the "surprise egg" videos on YouTube, according to James Bridle?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and boring.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too violent and disturbing.

options.label: C
options.text: They are designed to hack the brains of small children in return for advertising revenue.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not educational enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Finger Family Song" and why is it significant?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a popular children's song that is annoying to adults.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a catchy tune that has become a meme.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a song that has been used to create addictive content for small children.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a song that has been banned from YouTube.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the way YouTube's algorithm is designed, according to James Bridle?

options.label: A
options.text: It's too complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: It's too simple and easy to manipulate.

options.label: C
options.text: It's designed to prioritize advertising revenue over user well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: It's not able to detect and remove disturbing content.

multiple-choice.question: What is James Bridle's proposed solution to the problems with technology and social media?

options.label: A
options.text: To build more advanced AI systems to moderate content.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase digital literacy and education among users.

options.label: C
options.text: To make technology more legible and transparent to users.

options.label: D
options.text: To abolish technology and social media altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What is the broader societal issue that James Bridle believes is at the root of the problems with technology and social media?

options.label: A
options.text: Inequality of wealth and power.

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of education and digital literacy.

options.label: C
options.text: Concentration of power in the hands of a few individuals and corporations.

options.label: D
options.text: Over-reliance on technology and social media.

title: The life cycle of a neutron star - David Lunney

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a massive star when it runs out of fuel?

options.label: A
options.text: It expands into a black hole.

options.label: B
options.text: It collapses under its own gravitational pressure and explodes in a supernova.

options.label: C
options.text: It cools down and becomes a white dwarf.

options.label: D
options.text: It transforms into a neutron star without an explosion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the density of a neutron star's material equivalent to?

options.label: A
options.text: The mass of a car in a space of a basketball.

options.label: B
options.text: The mass of a fully-loaded container ship squeezed into a human hair.

options.label: C
options.text: The mass of a mountain in a space of a football field.

options.label: D
options.text: The mass of a planet in a space of a city block.

multiple-choice.question: Why do neutron stars spin rapidly?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are massive and have a strong gravitational pull.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are incredibly hot and have a lot of thermal energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their original star's angular momentum is preserved when they collapse.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are surrounded by a strong magnetic field.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the beams of radiation that radiate from a neutron star's magnetic poles?

options.label: A
options.text: Pulsars

options.label: B
options.text: Quasars

options.label: C
options.text: Black holes

options.label: D
options.text: Neutron beams

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon was predicted by Einstein's theory of General Relativity and directly verified in 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: The existence of black holes

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of neutron stars

options.label: C
options.text: The collision of two neutron stars sending gravity waves through space-time

options.label: D
options.text: The expansion of the universe
